description:
"On March 14, 2020, the President of the Republic decided to take measures to reduce contact and travel to the entire territory to the minimum as of March 16 at 12 a.m .:

A contingency plan triggered from today; mobile hospitals deployed by the national army,
Prohibition of all public demonstrations for one month
Cruise ships banned from entering Senegal
Schools and universities closed from Monday March 16
Suspension of Muslim and Christian pilgrimage procedures
Calls on the religious authorities to accompany the State in the measures adopted
Independence Day celebration 4 April canceled, instead a ceremony of taking up arms at the Palace will be organized
Calls on the Senegalese diaspora to respect the instructions issued in their country of residence
Violations of these rules will be penalized."
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)

description:
In Senegal, President Macky Sall installed a partial curfew in the regions of Dakar and Thiès starting the 6th of January 2021 from 9pm to 5am. 


 UPDATE: On the 20th of February, the Senegalese Minster of the Interior announced that given that the situation remains worrying in the regions of Dakar and Thiès, the curfew measures remain in effect until March 20th.

description: The state of emergency was first announced by the head of state on 23 March.

The state of emergency was first announced by the head of state on 23 March.
 UPDATE: On June 29th 2020, Senegalese President Macky Sall announced the lifting of the curfew and state of emergency against Covid-19 on the 30th of June 2020.
On January 5 2021, in Senegal, President Macky Sall declared a state of emergency in order to deal with the surge in new coronavirus contaminations recorded in the regions of Dakar and Thiès

description:
"On March 14, 2020, the President of the Republic decided to take measures to reduce contact and travel to the entire territory to the minimum as of March 16 at 12 a.m .:


Cruise ships banned from entering Senegal

Violations of these rules will be penalized."
 UPDATE: Update: Sengalese President Macky Sall announced the reopening of the air borders from July 15 2020. But there will be conditions: the head of state clarified that "international flights will resume according to a defined health protocol". And the reopening will also and above all depend on whether or not the borders are opened in the countries of destination.

The land and sea borders, however, remain closed until further notice.
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On July 1 2020, The President of Senegal "as part of strengthening vigilance in the fight against COVID-19, invited the Government to consolidate, in solidarity, the response and resilience capacities of the public health system. asked the ministers in charge of the Public Service, Health and the Budget to implement, without delay, his decision to have the State recruit, over the period 2020-2021, five one hundred (500) doctors and one thousand (1000) professional health workers (nurses, midwives and support staff)"

description:
On the 24th of March, the Minister of the Interior of Senegal published a mandate stating that the travel between the regions of Senegal is prohibited until further notice. 

Those exempt from this order are: 
-The President of the Republic 
-ministers and state secretaries
-Members of Parliament
-Ambassadors 
-Governors, prefects and sub-prefects as well as their deputies, -Magistrates and clerks 
-Personnel of the defense and security forces
-Health personnel 
-Vehicles transporting goods
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On the 27th of March, the Senegalese President released 2036 prisoners due to "Having had a capacity of 4000 detainees, the Senegalese prisons are said to have up to 12,000 people in prison. This overpopulation can prove to be fatal if the Covid-19 pandemic reaches certain areas of prison. This is what motivated the Senegalese President to distance those more vulnerable from prison."
type_sub_cat: Prison population reduced (e.g. early release of prisoners)
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
In Senegal the 4th of April parade and all other public manifestations to celebrate Senegal's Independence day are cancelled throughout the nation's territory. The Chief of the General Staff of the Armed Force of Senegal, Cheikh Wade, announced that this measure is taken in line with the measures adopted by the Senegalese government in the context of fighting against the spread of the Coronavirus.  

He urges all military and paramilitary personnel to show their commitment to the implementation of these rules decreed by the health authorities.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On the 25th of March the Senegalese government published a decree outlining the restrictive measures in the land transport sector for the fight against Covid-19: 
-The boarding of passengers in buses, minibuses and coaches providing public and private passenger transport is done with due regard to the seats and a distance of at least one (1) meter between the passengers.

-The entrances and exits of public transport stations must respect the health and safety measures adopted by the competent health authority

Any use of the urban passenger bus station not directly linked to transport activities is prohibited.

-The number of passengers on board private and public transportation vehicles is limited to half the number of seats indicated on the vehicle registration card.

-In the event that the number of seats in the vehicle is odd, the number of admissible passengers is the total number of seats divided by two.

-Drivers or public transportation employees must ensure that all the necessary hygiene rules are observed, in particular through the use of hydro-alcoholic products and hand washing

-The number of passengers on board city taxis or private vehicles with five (5) seats is limited to three (3), including the driver.

-The number of passengers on board vehicles with two wheels is one (1).
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on  private vehicles in public circulation
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On april 20, Senegal announced that masks are compulsory in administration, private sector, commerce and transport. UPDATE: The Ministerial decree n ° 011592 was published on July 10 enforcing the wearing of masks in administration, the private sector, commerce and transport for three months from that day onward.
